ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned to appreciate the design process more. You really appreciate everyday objects more when you yourself get to experience gathering information, prototyping etc.
How to use the resources of the CEID, soldering, and the entrepreneurial process.

You learn the basics of how a speaker works, circuitry, soldering, and how to operate a laser cutter. Beyond that, you can basically design a final project around the skills that you are interested in learning which is a really exciting process.

A lot of insight into how products that we use everyday are designed, and a look into the process of building a polished product from start to finish. Also computer aided design, 3D printing, laser cutter etc.
I learned about product design and innovation.
I learned a whole lot about the design process, especially on the pre-prototyping stages.
I got to learn how to use lots of the equipment in the CEID!
I learned about various stages of entrepreneurship. However, upon reflection, there were very few tangible things that I learned.
Learned a lot about product design and tech.
I learned hands-on building skills, ideation, and design skills, and got a look into the product design and startup space.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: very interesting and inspiring guest speakers, cool projects (you get to make your own Bluetooth speaker), you can possibly work on your invention

Weaknesses: its kind of hard to say what I've learned in this class. I really did enjoy it and I understand the design process more but like I cant really explain what genuine skills I've learned in class. Also the speaker project takes forever to make when it can realistically be done in 3 weeks. You only have 1 month for your final project which is soooo short. If we had more time the project would be so much more refined and more relaxing. Just felt it was rushed.

Strengths: A VERY dedicated teaching team, and it always felt like they wanted us to succeed. The subject is interesting, and it was taught very well.
Weaknesses: The guest speakers could be a hit and miss sometimes, and a quarter of the semester involved guest speakers, the class suffered.

The student projects are entirely student driven and organized. You have a lot of help available if you need it, but you are calling all the shots when it comes to organizing your project. It is a really empowering process.

The course could have used less speakers and more working sessions so students can be in the CEID during the hours in which design aides are paid to be there.
Prof Zinter and the teaching staff are the greatest strength. They spent so many hours outside of class with us helping on team projects!
I enjoyed working on the final project for the class. Starting earlier for More time to work on the final project would be helpful.

Strength: hands on nature of the course
Cons: the first part of the semester is rather slow paced

I think weaknesses are the reliance on teaching staff for support during the final project. Plus some of the speakers seemed kind of irrelevant to my interests personally, so I wish those events happened outside of class time/were offered to the broader Yale community. Strengths were getting to learn a ton of hands-on skills that are useful for building/making.

The course is very cool in that you are given the space to work in groups to create a real product. You also get to hear from cool speakers. I found some issues with the lack of substance that we actually learned. We spent the first half of the course working on the speaker. While I definitely thought it was cool, I do not think it was a good use of time. All the speakers came out looking identical as they were cookie-cutter speakers, so I do not think we learned very much from this process. I think the speaker project should be more open-ended or way more condensed (1 to 2 weeks). If the speaker is shortened we can spend more time on our projects, which I think would have been a better use of time. I think given it is a product design class, there should be more projects throughout the course where you can refine your product design skills. These do not need to be huge, but when you take out all creative freedom in the speaker, students do not actually learn anything. If you gave us the speaker and told us to build the casing for it, I think we would have gotten a lot more out of it as we would have to design and build it, causing students to think deeply about design.
Overall great course. Really engaging and you get to work on really fun projects.

Strengths: size, diversity of skill sets in the class, final projects, teaching staff. Weaknesses: scheduling, we spent a long time on the speaker project and I gained a lot more from the final project and wished we had more time on that, I wish we had gotten feedback more frequently, we didn't get anything back until after right at the end.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes I would definitely recommend this course to another Yalie. Especially if you are a senior mechanical engineer since this is a fun class to take for your senior project. There is no question that you have fun in this class, enjoy cool guest speakers. Joe is also a cool lecturer.
Yes! Do it. The professor really listens the feedback he receives, and I'm sure the class will continue to improve.

It is a great opportunity to learn new skills and familiarize yourself with the resources in the CEID! It's cool to work on your own project and decide what you want it to be and how you want it to take shape. While the first part of the semester is really relaxed, it definitely picks up in the final weeks. Prepare to spend a high proportion of your hours at the end of the semester working on this.
I would highly recommend this class to anyone interested in product design and entrepreneurship!
Yes, 100%. IDE recommend for every student at yale
yes!! very fun and interesting course

Probably not. I was very excited to do product design, but I do not think I got what I wanted out of the course. I barely learned about design and did not really design anything besides the final project.
Yes - you get a free speaker and a dope project. Really awesome for meeting people + learning more about your strengths.
I would recommend this class. It's pretty relaxed work-wise at the beginning but it ramps up a lot and you have to commit a ton of time at the end
